Headline.Para: Two Decades After Jonesboro Shooting, Survivors Still Haunted; 'We're affected every day, but we're alive and we're going forward,' a former student said about one of the first mass school shootings in U.S.

Snippet.Para: As thousands march in Washington to end gun violence, a small group will meet on a school playground in Jonesboro, Ark., to mark the 20th anniversary of one of the first mass school shootings in modern U.S. history.

Headline.Para: Two Decades After Jonesboro Shooting, Survivors Still Haunted; 'We're affected every day, but we're alive and we're going forward,' a former student said about one of the first mass school shootings in U.S.

LeadPara.Para: As thousands march in Washington to end gun violence, a small group will meet on a school playground in Jonesboro, Ark., to mark the 20th anniversary of one of the first mass school shootings in modern U.S. history.
On March 24, 1998, four students and a teacher were killed at Westside Middle School by two students who pulled a fire alarm and then shot at their classmates as they streamed out of the building.

TailParas.Para: "It's 20 years now and we're still wounded," said Jon Newman, whose best friend was one of the shooters. "The wounds don't go away."
Mr. Newman, now 32 years old and a high school teacher, is one of many Westside survivors who keep in touch on a Facebook page and check on each other when there is a school shooting.

The timing of the national march wasn't planned to coincide with the Jonesboro anniversary, say organizers of March for Our Lives. The national march and others like it around the country were put together after 17 people were killed in February at a high school in Parkland, Fla.
Krystal Oswald Scott, 31, said the memories of classmates falling around her, and her best friend dying 5 feet away, still haunt her.

She heard about the Parkland shooting on the car radio, and said she was glad her husband was driving. "It throws you straight into a panic attack, and you're right back in there in the gunfire," she said. "It was a hard thing, being 11 years old and going through something like that."

Chris "Topher" Scott, Krystal's husband, said it seems impossible that 20 years have passed and even more impossible that Westside has become a footnote to the string of mass shootings that have happened from Columbine, Colo., to Newtown, Conn.
"It's the severity," he said. "When 20 years ago, there was five killed, that was a big thing. Now it's 17, and that's just, I don't think anybody should have to go through that, especially kids."

But the Scotts and some other survivors in Jonesboro say solving the problem requires intervention for students in trouble. They live in a conservative part of northeast Arkansas outside Jonesboro, population 75,000. Hunting is a way of life, and the Scotts and others are ambivalent about gun restrictions.

Few survivors are planning to join an expected crowd of 100 people at the March for Our Lives in downtown Jonesboro Saturday morning. But Mr. Newman, who is an adviser to the student organizers, will be there.

Celeste Robinette, a 17-year-old high-school senior, said she reached out to survivors and to victims' parents to ask if they wanted to speak at the march, as some had called for tighter gun laws right after the shooting. No one took her up on it.
"A lot of the Westside parents haven't wanted to politicize anything," she said. "It was a long time ago."

Instead, many of the survivors, including the Scotts, plan to meet at a memorial garden that afternoon at the middle school. They will collect blank journals, with a goal of 3,400, one for every student enrolled at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School.
They plan to divvy up the journals and write a message of encouragement at the beginning of each one, and include a photo of the group they will take in the garden.

"I don't want to sell someone a story that the pain is going to go away," Mr. Newman said. "But we want to use the photo as proof that life does go on. We're on this field 20 years after this happened. We're affected everyday, but we're alive and we're going forward."
Write to Valerie Bauerlein at valerie.bauerlein@wsj.com
